docs.lead_paragraph: Fear of being stigmatized as an AIDS patient is still a major barrier to good care for pregnant young women in many countries, a new study and a literature review have found.

headline.seo: H.I.V. Stigma Is a Barrier to Prenatal Care, Study Finds
headline.main: Stigma of H.I.V. Is a Barrier to Prenatal Care
headline.print_headline: H.I.V.: Stigma of Disease Is a Barrier To Medical Care for Pregnant Women

docs.abstract: Dr Janet M Turan study in PLoS Medicine finds that fear of being stigmatized as an AIDS patient is still a major barrier to good medical care for pregnant young women in many countries
docs.snippet: Fear of being stigmatized as an AIDS patient is still a major barrier to good care for pregnant young women in many countries, a new study and a literature review have found.

docs.lead_paragraph: Monday was a day of frustration for Republicans as the delay in beginning their convention deprived them of their national stage and brought a fresh airing of intraparty tensions.

headline.main: As Storm Disrupts Plans, G.O.P. Takes Up Tensions
headline.print_headline: As Storm Disrupts Plans, G.O.P. Takes Up Tensions

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney and top aides, worried that Tropical Storm Isaac could cause further disruption, head to Tampa, Fla, to quickly hold roll call vote to officially make him the Republican Party's presidential nominee; party leaders gavel convention to mark its formal opening and then quickly call a recess; frustration over delay brings fresh airing of intraparty tensions.
docs.snippet: Monday was a day of frustration for Republicans as the delay in beginning their convention deprived them of their national stage and brought a fresh airing of intraparty tensions.

byline.contributor: Jeff Zeleny, William Storey and Susan Saulny contributed reporting.
byline.original: By JIM RUTENBERG and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to medical care, many patients and doctors believe more is better. But an epidemic of overtreatment - too many scans, too many blood tests, too many procedures - is costing the nation's health care system at least $210 billion a year, according to the Institute of Medicine, and taking a human toll in pain, emotional suffering, severe complications and even death.

headline.main: Overtreatment Is Taking a Harmful Toll

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column argues that an epidemic of overtreatment--excessive scans, tests and procedures--is costing the nation's health care system at least $210 billion a year; notes that the trend also exacts a significant human toll in the form of pain, emotional suffering, severe complications and even death. Photos, Drawing (M)/
docs.snippet: When it comes to medical care, many patients and doctors believe more is better.   But an epidemic of overtreatment - too many scans, too many blood tests, too many procedures - is costing the nation's health care system at least $210 billion a year,...

headline.main: Overtreatment Is Taking a Harmful Toll
headline.print_headline: Overtreatment Is Taking a Harmful Toll

docs.abstract: An epidemic of overtreatment is costing the health care system at least $210 billion a year, and patients are paying the price in pain, emotional suffering, severe complications and even death.
docs.snippet: An epidemic of overtreatment is costing the health care system at least $210 billion a year, and patients are paying the price in pain, emotional suffering, severe complications and even death.

docs.lead_paragraph: Few voters are unfamiliar with Representative Todd Akin’s reference to “legitimate rape,” so Senator Claire McCaskill has not seen the need to bring it up.

headline.seo: McCaskill Treads Cautiously on Akin’s Comments on Rape
headline.main: Her Opponent Stumbles, but a Candidate Still Watches Her Step
headline.print_headline: Opponent Made the Stumble, but a Candidate Still Watches Her Step

docs.abstract: Sen Claire McCaskill of Missouri, fending off a re-election challenge from Rep Todd Akin, has avoided commenting on Akin's recent controversial statements on abortion and rape; McCaskill feels that Akin's comments have already received widespread publicity, and that abortion is a dangerously volatile subject in her socially conservative state.
docs.snippet: Few voters are unfamiliar with Representative Todd Akin’s reference to “legitimate rape,” so Senator Claire McCaskill has not seen the need to bring it up.

byline.contributor: John Eligon contributed reporting from Alton, Ill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nicole Polizzi, the star of MTV’s “Jersey Shore” who is better known as Snooki, gave birth to her first child.
docs.abstract: Nicole Polizzi, the star of MTV reality television series Jersey Shore who is better known as Snooki, gives birth to her first child.
docs.snippet: Nicole Polizzi, the star of MTV’s “Jersey Shore” who is better known as Snooki, gave birth to her first child.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company has agreed to sell the About Group, which includes the About.com network of topic sites, to Barry Diller 's IAC/InterActiveCorp for about $300 million in cash, the company said on Sunday. The deal, which is expected to close in the next several weeks, continues a corporate overhaul that is refocusing The Times on its core newspaper and Web site operations.

headline.main: Times Agrees To Sell About To Diller's IAC

docs.abstract: New York Times Company agrees to sell the About Group, which includes the About.com network of topic sites, to Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp for about $300 million in cash; deal beats an earlier $270 million offer from Answers.com (M)0

docs.lead_paragraph: Louie Gohmert has become a bête noire for liberal commentators, but his district keeps re-electing him.

headline.seo: Louie Gohmert, Texas Republican, Notorious Yet Popular

docs.lead_paragraph: Future doctors will need to correct the postmodern tendency toward immune dysregulation.

headline.main: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism
headline.print_headline: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Moises Velasquez-Manoff notes current research suggesting that a subset of autism may be caused by an inflammatory disease in the womb; concludes work toward correcting maternal immune dysregulation may contribute to the prevention of autism.
docs.snippet: Future doctors will need to correct the postmodern tendency toward immune dysregulation.
